user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Lock_Global_Impl:
```c
void OS_Lock_Global_Impl(osal_objtype_t idtype)
{
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;
    int                     ret;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];

    if (impl != NULL)
    {
        ret = pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->mutex);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->mutex): %s", strerror(ret));
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Lock_Global_Impl:
OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *const OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER] = {
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED]   = NULL,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK]     = &OS_global_task_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE]    = &OS_queue_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM] = &OS_count_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM]   = &OS_bin_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX]    = &OS_mutex_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM]   = &OS_stream_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR]      = &OS_dir_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE] = &OS_timebase_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB]   = &OS_timecb_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE]   = &OS_module_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS]  = &OS_filesys_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE]  = &OS_console_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR]  = &OS_condvar_lock,
}
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    pthread_cond_t  cond;
} OS_impl_objtype_lock_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code was identified in the provided fragments. OS_Lock_Global_Impl contains a simple sequence: table lookup, a null check, and an attempt to lock the mutex only when impl != NULL — both the true and false outcomes of the if-statement are reachable at run time (e.g. OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED yields impl == NULL; other valid object types yield non-NULL pointers). The initializer for OS_impl_objtype_lock_table contains explicit entries (including a NULL for the undefined type), which does not introduce any statically unreachable statements. Note that there are other potential concerns (out-of-bounds indexing if idtype can be invalid, use of strerror with a pthread error code) but these are runtime/UB or API-usage issues rather than examples of unreachable code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1, so they do not warrant marking fragments as unreachable.
